gurmukhi: jw ko lKXo kubjw bl bwhn jwko lKXo mur dYq AqMkw ]rIJ bjwie auTXo murlI soeI jIiq dIXo js ko mno fMkw ]649]
transliteration: Jaa Ko Lakhyo Koubjaa Bal Baahan Jaako Lakhyo Mur Dait Atankaa|| Reejh Bajaae Outhyo Murlisoijeet(i) Deeyo Jas Ko Mano Dankaa||649||
translation: The servant Kubja was saved by his gracious glance and the demon named Mur was destroyed by his looks; the same Krishna causing the blaring of the drum of his praise, played on his flute.649.

gurmukhi: rUKn qy rs cUvn lwg JrY Jrnw igr qy suKdweI ]Gws cugY n miRgw bn ky Kg rIJ rhy Dun jw sun pweI ]
transliteration: Rookhan Te Ras Choovan Laag Jdarai Jharnaa Gir Te Soukhdaaee|| Ghaas Chougad Na Mrigad Ban Ke Khag Reejh Rahe Dhoun Jaa Soun Paaee||
translation: On hearing the sound of the flute, the sap of the trees began to drip and peace-giving currents flowed, on hearing it, deer abandoned the grazing of grass and the birds of the forest also were fascinated;

gurmukhi: dyvgMDwr iblwvl swrMg kI irJ kY ijh qwn bsweI ]dyv sBY imil dyKq kauqk jau murlI nMd lwl bjweI ]650]
transliteration: Devgaddhaar Bilaaval Saaran Kirijh Kai Jih Taan Basaaee|| Dev Sabhai Mil(i) Dekhat Kaoutak Jau Murlinand Taal Bajaee||650||
translation: The tunes of the musical modes of Devgandhar, Bilawal and Sarang were played from the flute and seeing Krishna, the son of Nand, playing on the flute, the god also got together to visualize the scene.650.

gurmukhi: TwF rhI jmunw sun kY Dun rwg Bly sunby ko chy hY ]moih rhy bn ky gj Aau iekTy imil Awvq isMG shy hY ]
transliteration: Thaadh Rahijamounnda Soun Kai Dhoun Raag Bhale Sounbe Ko Chahe Hai|| Moh(i) Rahe Ban Ke Gad Au Ikathe Mil(i) Aavat Singh Sahe Hai||
translation: With the desire of listening to the music, Yamuna also became motionless; the elephants, lions and rabbits of the forest are also getting allured;

gurmukhi: Awvq hY sur mMfl ky sur qXwg sBY sur DXwn PhY hY ]so suin kY bn ky Kgvw qr aUpr pMK pswr rhy hY ]651]
transliteration: Oovat Hai Sur Mandal Ke Sur Tyaag Sabhai Sur Tyaag Sabhai Sur Dhyaan Phahai Hai|| So Soun(i) Kai Ban Ke Khagvaa Tar Oopar Pankh Pasaar Rahe Hai||651||
translation: The gods also, abandoning the heaven, are coming under the impact of the tune of flute; hearing the sound of the same flute, the birds of the forest, spreading their wings on the trees, are absorbed in it.651.

gurmukhi: joaU gÍwrin Kylq hY hir so Aiq hI ihq kY n kCU Dn mY ]Aiq suMdr pY ijh bIc lsY Pun kMcn kI su pRBw qn mY ]
transliteration: Jooo Gvaaran(i) Khelat Hai Har(i) So At(i) Hikai Na Kachhodh Dhan Mai|| At(i) Soundar Pai Jih Beech Lasai Phoun Kanchanndkisu Phabhaa Tan Mai||
translation: The gopis, who are playing with Krishna, have extreme love in their mind; very who have the bodies of gold, are extremely winsome;

gurmukhi: joaU cMdR muKI kt kyhir sI su ibrwjq gÍwrin ky gin mY ]suin kY murlI Dun sRaunn mY Aiq rIJ igrI su mno bn mY ]652]
transliteration: Jooo Channdra Moukhikat Kehar(i) Sisu Biraajat Gvaaran(i) Ke Gad(i) Mai|| Soun(i) Kai Murlidhoun Sraounan Mai At(i) Reejh Girisu Mano Ban Mai||652||
translation: The gopi named Chandarmukhi, having slim waist like lion, appears splendid amongst other gopis, hearing the sound of the flute and being fascinated, she fell down.652.

gurmukhi: ieh kauqk kY su cly giH ko Pun gwvq gIq hlI hir AwCy ]suMdr bIc AKwry ikDO kib sXwm khY ntUAw jn kwCy ]
transliteration: Eh Kaoutak Kai Su Chale Grih Ko Phoun Gadvat Geet Halihar(i) Aachhe|| Soondar Beech Akhdare Kidhau Kabi Syaam Kahai Natooaa Jan Kaadhhe||
translation: Having performed this wonderful play, Krishna and Balram came home singing; the beautiful arenas and dancing theatres in the city have a magnificent look;

gurmukhi: rwjq hY blB`dR ky nYn XyN mwnoN Fry ieh mYn ky swCy ]suMdr hY riq ky piq qY Aiq mwnhu fwrq mYnih pwCy ]653]
transliteration: Raajat Hai Baldhaddra Ke Nain Yon Maanon Ddare Eh Main Daarat Mainah(i) Paachhe||653||
translation: The eyes of Balram appear to have been prepared in the mould of god of love; they are so charming that the god of love feels shy.653.

gurmukhi: bIc mnY suK pwie qbY giH kO su cly irp kO hin doaU ]cMdRpRBw sm jw muK au`pm jw sm au`pm hY nih koaU ]
transliteration: Beech Manai Soukh Paae Tabai Gih Kau Su Chale Rip Kau Han(i) Dooo|| Channdraprabhaa Sam Jaa Moukh Ouppam Jaa Sam Ouppam Hai Nah(i) Kooo||
translation: Being pleased in the mind and killing the enemy, both have gone away to their home; they have the faces like moon, which can’t be compared with any other;

gurmukhi: dyKq rIJ rhY ijh ko irp rIJiq so ien dyKq soaU ]mwnhu lCmn rwm bfy Bt mwr cly irp ko Gr EaU ]654]
transliteration: Dekhat Reejh Rahai Jih Ko Rip Reejhat(i) So In Dekhat Sooo|| Maanoh Lachman Raam Bade Bhat Maar Chale Rip Ko Ghar Ooo||654||
translation: Seeing them, the enemies are also charmed and they appeared like Ram and Lakshman returning to their home after killing the enemy.654.
Now beings the description of playing in the street-chamber
